Literature Review: Pari-mutuel betting markets, particularly those associated with racetracks and lotteries, have long been a subject of fascination for economists and financial researchers. These markets offer unique insights into human behavior, market efficiency, and the interplay between risk and reward. This literature review aims to explore the current state of research in this field, focusing on market efficiency, pricing mechanisms, and recent developments since the seminal work of Thaler & Ziemba (1988).The efficiency of racetrack betting markets has been a central theme in the literature. Sauer (1998) provided a comprehensive review of the existing research up to that point, highlighting the persistent anomalies observed in these markets, such as the favorite-longshot bias. This bias, where favorites tend to be underbet and longshots overbet, has been consistently documented across various racing jurisdictions and time periods (Snowberg & Wolfers, 2010).One of the most significant developments in the field has been the application of stochastic programming optimization models to racetrack betting. As noted by Hausch et al. (1981), these models have transformed racetrack betting from a mere handicapping exercise into a sophisticated financial market. This shift has allowed professional syndicates to operate in a manner akin to hedge funds, exploiting market inefficiencies for profit.The concept of arbitrage, both in its pure and risk-based forms, has been extensively studied in the context of pari-mutuel markets. Hausch & Ziemba (1990) demonstrated the theoretical possibility of pure arbitrage in exotic bet types, such as exactas and trifectas. However, practical limitations often prevent the full exploitation of these opportunities. Risk arbitrage, on the other hand, involves taking calculated risks based on perceived mispricings and has been shown to be a more viable strategy for professional bettors (Edelman, 2007).The role of syndicates in pari-mutuel markets has garnered increasing attention in recent years. These professional betting operations leverage advanced statistical models and substantial capital to gain an edge over the average bettor. Gramm et al. (2016) examined the impact of syndicate activity on market efficiency, finding that their presence tends to improve overall market accuracy while potentially crowding out smaller, less sophisticated bettors.A relatively new phenomenon in racetrack betting is the emergence of betting exchange rebates. These rebates, offered by some betting platforms, effectively reduce the track take and can significantly alter the profitability calculus for high-volume bettors. Woodland & Woodland (2003) investigated the impact of these rebates on market efficiency and betting behavior, concluding that they can potentially exacerbate existing market anomalies.Behavioral biases continue to play a crucial role in pari-mutuel markets. Beyond the well-documented favorite-longshot bias, researchers have identified numerous other cognitive quirks that influence betting behavior. For instance, Jullien & Salanié (2000) explored the impact of loss aversion on racetrack betting, while Kopelman & Minkin (1991) examined the role of anchoring and adjustment in lottery number selection.The distinction between fundamental information and mispricing information in racetrack and lottery markets has been a subject of ongoing research. Fundamental information relates to the true probabilities of outcomes, while mispricing information pertains to discrepancies between market prices and these true probabilities. Asch et al. (1984) demonstrated that successful betting strategies often rely on a combination of both types of information.Interestingly, the models and insights derived from pari-mutuel betting markets have found applications beyond their original domain. Several researchers have explored the potential for applying similar approaches to stock market anomalies. For example, Hausch et al. (2008) drew parallels between betting market strategies and quantitative trading in financial markets, suggesting that the lessons learned from racetracks and lotteries could inform more general investment strategies.The lottery market, while sharing some similarities with racetrack betting, presents its own unique characteristics and challenges. Clotfelter & Cook (1993) provided a comprehensive analysis of state lotteries, examining their economic impact and the factors driving participation. More recent research has focused on optimal lottery design and the potential for exploiting structural inefficiencies in certain lottery games (Grote & Matheson, 2011).In conclusion, the field of pari-mutuel betting markets continues to evolve, driven by technological advancements, regulatory changes, and ongoing academic interest. While many of the fundamental principles identified in earlier research remain relevant, new developments such as betting exchanges, rebate systems, and sophisticated syndicate operations have added layers of complexity to these markets. As research in this area progresses, it promises to yield further insights not only into the specific dynamics of racetracks and lotteries but also into broader questions of market efficiency, behavioral finance, and optimal investment strategies.
